detail.content: Eng: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama          Drama   Steven Eng Instructor Phone: 212 875 7435 Email: seng@nyu.edu Website: http://www.voxeng.com/ Office: 721 Broadway, 3rd Floor Office Hours: None  Courses Freshman Speech,  Sophomore Voice,  Junior Voice Education MFA Classical Acting - Shakespeare Theatre Company's Academy for Classical Acting at The George Washington University BFA Theatre - Southern Methodist University, minor in Music Vocal Performance   Biography Steven teaches voice and speech in NYC. In addition to private instruction, he has served as voice and text coach on numerous productions with ShakespeareNYC. In workshops, he has taught professional actors and high school students, from Shakespeare verse to audition techniques. He is also a certified Associate Teacher of Fitzmaurice Voicework® and has served as a panelist at the Voice and Speech Trainers Association national conference. As a professional actor, Steven has performed internationally in London’s West End, Germany, Austria, and Cambodia, as well as with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, South Dakota Symphony, Off-Broadway, and noted NY theaters including Ensemble Studio Theatre, Prospect Theater Company, Pan Asian Repertory, and ShakespeareNYC. He has performed with major regional theaters across ! the U.S., including Paper Mill Playhouse, La Jolla Playhouse, the Alliance Theater, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, North Shore Music Theater, Dallas Theater Center, Huntington Theater, Barrington Stage, Theatre Under the Stars, Triad Stage (NC), Shakespeare Festival of Dallas, Fort Worth Shakespeare in the Park, and on national tour. Steven has also served as Director/Choreographer’s Assistant on Broadway, Off-Broadway, NYC Opera, and national tours. He is also a co-founder of National Asian Artists Project in NYC (naaproject.org). Steven is a proud member of Actors Equity and SAG-AFTRA. Spector: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama          Drama   Daniel Spector Teacher and Associate Director The Classical Studio Phone: 212 992 9344 Email: daniel.spector@nyu.edu Office: 721 Broadway, 3rd Floor Office Hours: Variable  Courses The Classical Studio, Workshop in Shakespearean Verse, Heightened Language, Audition/Casting Education B.F.A., M.A., New York University Biography   Daniel Spector has directed or coached actors on 35 productions of 25 Shakespeare plays. He's even directed a non-Shakespeare play: “Shakespeare’s R & J." Most recently, he directed “Othello” for the Kinetic Theater Ensemble. Daniel is a member of the Lincoln Center Theater Directors Lab and is an alumnus of the Broadway Theatre Project. He has served as the Director of Training for the New York Neo-Classical Ensemble and directed their inaugural production of “Love’s Labor’s Lost” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. He has served as a consultant to PBS on matters Shakespearean, moderated Artist Talks at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, led workshops for the Oklahoma Arts Institute, and produced many readings of new plays. A frequent collaborator in the classroom, he has taught with Alec Baldwin, Louis Scheeder, and Tim Carroll. Daniel holds a joint appointment with the Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing and the Department of Drama. Workshop in Shakespearean Verse: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama        Workshop in Shakespearean Verse  H28.0146 Seminar 2 Credits Instructor(s): Louis Scheeder The course concentrates on the text of Shakespeare’s plays and how to use the text as a guide for the actor to achieve the character’s intentions. Emphasis is placed on analysis of the verse, how to speak it, and how to use it to create character. Students prepare monologues, soliloquies, set speeches, and sonnets for presentation in class.
